clinical_study.official_title: Forearm Blood Flow Response to Acute Consumption of Black Tea

brief_summary.textblock: The study will explore the benefit of tea for microcirculation. Subjects will consume tea ar a placebo matched for taste and appearance in a blinded cross over design.

detailed_description.textblock:
Epidemiological studies indicate that regular consumption of black tea reduces the risk of cardiovascular diseases. Tea consumption can result in improvements in endothelial function of conduit arteries as measured by flow mediated dilation.
Less is known however about its effects in other vascular beds. The study will test the hypothesis that tea affects endothelial function in the muscle microcirculation. This will be done by assessment of forearm blood flow using venous occlusion plethysmography after consumption of black tea against or placebo in a randomised, full cross-over study in 20 healthy middle-aged to elderly subjects

study_design_info.masking: Quadruple (Participant, Care Provider, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor)

primary_outcome.measure: Forearm blood flow response to acetylcholine
primary_outcome.time_frame: During acetylcholine infusion 120-140 min after first tea/placebo intake
primary_outcome.description: Does tea ingestion change mean forearm blood flow response to acetylcholine when compared to placebo

secondary_outcome.measure: Forearm blood flow response to sodium nitropusside
secondary_outcome.time_frame: During sodium nitropusside infusion 170-190 min after first tea/placebo intake
secondary_outcome.description: Does tea ingestion change mean forearm blood flow response to sodium nitropusside when compared to placebo

secondary_outcome.measure: Forearm blood flow response to L-NMMA
secondary_outcome.time_frame: During L-NMMA infusion 220-240 min after first tea/placebo intake
secondary_outcome.description: Does tea ingestion change mean forearm blood flow response to L-NG-monomethyl Arginine (L-NMMA) when compared to placebo

arm_group.description: Approximately 400 mg total polyphenols in 240 ml hot water (loading dose; 2 hours before the start of measurements; t=0) and 130 mg total polyphenols in 120 ml hot water (maintenance dose just before start of the measurements; t=120 min)

Caramel colour, maltodextrin and tea flavour in 240 ml hot water (2 hours before the start of measurements; t=0) and 120 ml hot water (maintenance dose just before start of the measurements; t=120 min)

intervention.description: Black tea infusion equivalent to approximately 530 mg total polyphenols expressed as gallic acid equivalents
Placebo matched to tea with respect to taste and appearance

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Males and post menopausal (> 1 years) females
- Aged ≥ 45 and ≤ 75 years
- Body mass index (BMI) of ≥ 18.0 and ≤ 35.0 kg/m2
- Judged to be in good health on the basis of medical history, physical examination and routine laboratory tests (total cholesterol, HDL cholesterol, LDL cholesterol, triglycerides, glucose, highly sensitive C-reactive protein).
- Normal blood coagulation as assessed by routine lab tests
Exclusion Criteria:
- Strenuous exercise > 2 hours per week. Strenuous exercise is defined as exercise which induces sweating and causes sufficient breathlessness to limit conversation
- Current smoker or has stopped smoking less than 6 months before start of study
- Self reported alcohol intake of > 21 units/week)
- Established cardiovascular disease or clinically significant arrhythmia
- Diabetes mellitus
- Blood pressure > 160/100 mmHg
- Taking medication that might affect endothelial function (as judged by the PI)
